developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content: The volcanic island of Saint Lucia is 238 square miles and home to 183,627 people. The country is known for its Piton Mountains and lush rainforests, covering approximately 77% of the island. Saint Lucia is classified as a middle-income small island developing state (SIDS). Saint Lucia has a relatively high level of biological and ecosystem diversity. Population centres and economic activities, including tourism, are concentrated along the coast. The economy of Saint Lucia is dominated by tourism and banana production, with some activity from small-scale manufacturing. Tourism’s direct contribution to GDP of 15.61 percent (2018) increases by 2.71 percent on a year-on-year average. In Saint Lucia, 1.9 percent of the population are multidimensionally poor. As a SIDS, with significant vulnerabilities to external economic shocks, the impacts of natural disasters and effects of climate change, Saint Lucia recognizes fully that sustainable development with a focus on people, planet, prosperity, partnerships and peace has to be at the core of national plans and programmes, in order to meet the needs of present and future generations.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Saint Lucia’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.759— which puts the country in the high human development category— positioning it at 86 out of 189 countries and territories. Between 1990 and 2019, Saint Lucia’s life expectancy at birth increased by 5.1 years, mean years of schooling increased by 1.5 years and expected years of schooling increased by 1.4 years. Saint Lucia’s GNI per capita increased by about 74.6 percent between 1990 and 2019. In 2019, 20.7 percent of parliamentary seats are held by women. Saint Lucia has made meaningful strides in the implementation of SDGs 3 and 4 on health and education. Poverty levels declined between 2006 and 2016 from 28.8 percent to 25 percent.

Saint Lucia is a founding member of the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States and hosts the Organisation’s headquarters as well as the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court.

The Government of Saint Lucia has demonstrated its commitment to responding to climate change by taking a proactive role at the international, regional and national levels. The Government of Saint Lucia has implemented a range of projects over the years, largely focused on adaptation, but also including mitigation.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
Saint Lucia is characterized by: limited mineral resources; an open fragile economy highly vulnerable to external economic factors; limited human resources; limited financial and technical resources.  Limits to adaptation include the inability of coastal ecosystems to adapt to increased sea level rise, insufficient financial resources to implement required adaptation strategies, and the lack of effective or affordable technology to provide coastal protection from sea level rise and other slow onset events and extreme events. Barriers are mainly related to institutional, financial, and policy obstacles.

Human, technological, and institutional capacity constraints also contribute to a particular set of challenges that retard Saint Lucia’s effective implementation of the SDGs. The island’s reefs are subject to damage from land-based pollutants and sedimentation, which has threatened near-shore fisheries.

There is still a critical need to strengthen the national statistical system, in order to adequately track and measure progress at the national level. Challenges also persist in the collection, analysis and dissemination of linked economic, social and environmental data.

Despite the progress in education and in the labour force, women in Saint Lucia are still exposed to specific gender challenges.
